Description: Mural on wall across from Jackson Square T Station
Mural on façade of Pimentel Market on Centre Street and Wyman Street

Mural on back of Whole Foods depicting the tribe's wind goddess Huraca'n, from which the word for a tropical storm is derived.  She is flanked by two gods Guatauba and Coatrisque, who represent in Taino mythology the respective powers of thunder and flooding water. The mural grew out of Boston's relationship with Dorado, Puerto Rico, and "affirmed JP and Hi-Lo (the grocery store replaced by Whole Foods in 2011) as the heart of Boston's Latino community."

Mural along eastern wall of Mozart Park

"Reach" is composed of five 8”x 8” stainless steel square tubes and creates the form of a 25-foot monumental hand. The sculpture symbolizes the immigrant experience of reaching up to climb the ladder of success in America. The form of a hand is only visible from the central axis of the park. From all other vantage points, the sculpture appears abstract. Each upright of the sculpture has two engraved quotations at eye level. The quotations were written by youth who live in the Hyde Square neighborhood and describe their, or their family’s, experiences as immigrants in America. The joints of the contorted uprights are purposely left exposed to symbolize the different turning points or changes in the life of an American immigrant.
